div.p: Two kinds of work
Jonathan Furner
GSE&IS, UCLA
VRA :: March 29, 2007
Cataloging cultural objects
cultural objects
works
works of visual art
built works
cultural artifacts
documentary images
CCO: What is a work?
a distinct intellectual or artistic creation limited
primarily to [physical] objects and structures made by humans
excluded are literary works, musical works, works in
the performing arts, and other intangible culture
CCO: What is an image?
a visual representation [or depiction] of a work
a surrogate for a work that documents it
typically in photographic, photomechanical, or digital
format
i.e., what is held in visual resources collections
CCO: What is an image? contd
always excluded are paintings, drawings, sculpture, and
as works themselves
some photographs that depict works may similarly be
treated as works themselves
depending on the stature of the photographer and the
aesthetic or historical value of the photograph
CCOs entity--relationship model
Work
Image
Source
Personal and corporate name
Geographic place
Concept
Subject
(see Fig. 1, p. 20)
Treatment of depicted works
the work depicted in an image should be treated as a Related Work of that image
similarly, any image depicting a work should be treated as a Related Image of that work
if a work depicts another work, the depicted work should be treated as a Subject of the work at hand (see CCO 6.2.1.2.8)
if the depicted work is described in its own catalog record, then it should also be treated as a Related Work of the work at hand
Some examples of complex relationships
a photo by Durandelle of the Eiffel Tower: http://www.vraweb.org/ccoweb/cco/example57.html
Work: Eiffel Tower
Work: photo
Some examples of complex relationships, contd
an image of a plan of a building, and an image of the building
Work: building Image
Work: plan Image
Some examples of complex relationships, contd
Is the work-to-be-cataloged the manuscript page, or the photo?
Some examples of complex relationships, contd
Work: sarcophagus
Work: manuscript page Image: photo
Work: sarcophagus
Work: manuscript page
Work: photo Image: slide
option A
option B
Work in CCO vs. Work in FRBR/RDA
note 2, p. 41: Work in CCO is more concrete
than work as defined in FRBR ... The work in
CCO is usually a physical entity, whereas that in
FRBR is an abstraction or intellectual entity, such
as a literary work or a musical composition.
FRBRs E-R model (simplified)
Work
Expression
Manifestation
Item
Person
Corporate body
Concept
Object
Event
Place
Group 1 Group 2 Group 3
FRBRs Group 1 entities
a work is a distinct intellectual or artistic creation ... an
abstract entity
an expression is the specific intellectual or artistic
form that a work takes each time it is realized; the
intellectual or artistic realization of a work in the form of
alpha-numeric, musical, or choreographic notation, sound,
image, object, movement, etc., or any combination of such
forms
FRBRs Group 1 entities, contd

a manifestation is the physical embodiment of an expression of a work ... [the set of] all the physical objects that bear the same characteristics, in respect to both intellectual content and physical form
an item is a single exemplar [or instance] of a manifestation ... a concrete entity ... in many instances a single physical object
FRBRs Group 1 entities, contd
Works ... are realized through
Expressions ... are embodied in
Manifestations ... are exemplified by
Items
A literary example
work: Cervantes Don Quixote
expression: Grossmans English translation of Don Quixote
manifestation: Eccos 2003 edition of Grossmans text
item: my copy of Eccos 2003 edition
A musical example
work: Andersson, Ulvaeus, and Andersons Dancing queen
expression: Abbas performance of Dancing queen
recorded in 1975
manifestation: the recording released as a single in
item: my copy of the single
An example from the visual arts
work: Magrittes The human condition
expression: the specific realization [in 1935] of [The human condition] in the form of ... an image
manifestation: [the set of] all the physical objects that [share] the same ... intellectual content [as that expression] and physical form
item: the instance of The human condition hanging in a private collection
Ontology of art
a subfield of the philosophy of art
What sorts of things are works of art?
What is the nature of the various sorts of relationship that exist between works of art and things of other sorts?
In what does the identity of a work of art (of a given sort) consist?
Are translations ... cover versions ... directors cuts ... new works, or just different expressions of the same work?
Why worry?
designers of catalogs need to know how records
should be grouped and linked so that catalog
users can find the objects they want
FRBR, Lubetzky, Cutter ... : records representing
objects should be grouped by the works they
instantiate
Philosophers views on ontology of literature
most see literary works as (Peircean) types, each instantiated by multiple tokens
types tokens
word-types word-occurrences
sentences utterances
works copies
Philosophers views on ontology of literature, contd
a type can be characterized as:
a fixed sequence of words in a given language (Goodman)
a fixed sequence of words specifying what counts as a correct
instance (Wolterstorff: norm kind)
a fixed sequence of words indicated by a given author at a given
time (Levinson)
a fixed sequence of words arrived at by an authors following a
given set of contextual influences (Currie: action type)
Philosophers views on ontology of literature, contd
some see works as megatypes
the (propositional) meaning shared by two instances -including paraphrases, translations, etc. (Stevenson)
megatypes types tokens
concepts word-types word-occurrences
propositions sentences utterances
works translations copies
Philosophers views on ontology of art
uniform theories
unitive theories: the type/token distinction isnt characteristic of
any arts
there are neither types nor tokens (Collingwood)
there are no tokens (Currie)
there are no types (Goodman): CCO?
dualist theories: the type/token distinction is characteristic of all
arts: FRBR?
Philosophers views on ontology of art, contd
non-uniform theories
the type/token distinction is characteristic of some
arts, but not others (Wolterstorff, Davies)
singular works: paintings, hewn sculptures, Polaroids, many
buildings
type-works that can have multiple tokens: cast
sculptures, photographs from negatives, prints (as well as
literary works, theatrical works, and musical works)
Two and a half questions
Should CCO be modified to reflect a FRBResque view of the relationships existing between (abstract) type-works and (concrete) token-items -- and if so, how?
Should FRBR be modified to reflect a CCOesque view of the relationships existing between (concrete) works and (concrete) images -- and if so, how?
If images are type-works, how useful is the work/image distinction?
Is image more usefully conceived as a Work Type than as a Record Type?
Bibliography
Baca, Murtha, et al. (2006). Cataloging cultural objects: A guide to describing cultural works and their images. Chicago, IL: American Library Association.
IFLA Study Group on the Functional Requirements for Bibliographic Records. (1998). Functional requirements for bibliographic records. Mnchen: K. G. Saur.
Stevenson, C. L. (1957). On What is a poem? Philosophical Review 66: 329-362.
Wolterstorff, N. (1992). Ontology of artworks. In A companion to aesthetics, ed. D. Cooper, 310-314. Oxford: Blackwell.
Howell, R. (2002). Ontology and the nature of the literary work. Journal of Aesthetics and Art Criticism 60: 67-79.
Thomasson, A. L. (2003). The ontology of art. In The Blackwell guide to aesthetics, ed. P. Kivy, 78-92. Oxford: Blackwell.
Davies, S. (2006). Varieties of art. In The philosophy of art, 81-108. Oxford: Blackwell.
